title: Z-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Proportions
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental tool in statistical hypothesis testing, allowing us to determine whether a sample is representative of a larger population.

Given a set of data, we can use Z-tests to compare the mean or proportion of our sample to a known value or another sample.
name: Standardized Normal Variable" },
intuition: The key insight here is that Z-tests rely on the Central Limit Theorem, which states that the sample mean will be approximately normally distributed for large enough samples. This allows us to standardize our data and compare it to a known value or another sample.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the effectiveness of different marketing strategies
Analyzing the impact of climate change on species populations
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions, such as normality or equal variances

subject: statistics
title: Z-Tests: One-Sample, Two-Sample, and Proportions
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental concept in mathematical statistics that allow us to make inferences about population parameters based on sample data.

Given a random sample from a normal distribution with known standard deviation, we can use z-tests to determine whether the sample mean is significantly different from a hypothesized value or another sample mean.
name: Z-statistic" },
intuition: The z-test is a powerful tool for making inferences about population means when the standard deviation is known. It's widely used in machine learning and AI applications to compare the performance of different models or evaluate the effectiveness of treatments.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the accuracy of two classification algorithms
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions, such as normality

subject: statistics
title: Z-Tests: A Statistical Tool for One-Sample and Two-Sample Problems
contentHtml:
Z-tests are a fundamental concept in statistical hypothesis testing, allowing us to determine whether a sample mean or proportion deviates significantly from a known population parameter.

In this card, we'll explore the intuition behind Z-tests, including one-sample and two-sample problems, as well as proportions. We'll also discuss common misconceptions and real-world applications, especially in machine learning and artificial intelligence.
intuition: A Z-test is essentially a statistical way to determine whether our sample mean or proportion is 'far away' from the known population parameter. This is useful in machine learning when we want to determine if our model's performance is significantly better than chance.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the average rating of a new restaurant versus an existing one
commonMistakes: Failing to check assumptions, such as normality or equal variances
